text.tspan: alpha = vectorAngle(a,b) == angle at corner pBefore.
where the vector length of acceleration must be below the limit!
The acceleration is possible under the limit as long as c_max <= acceleration_max * time_min.
In this case, c_max >= sin(alpha) * a
case 1b: at the acceleration limit, at the edge between possible and impossible
if the length of b is arbitrary: impossible as soon as c < sin(alpha) * a
Design document for the speed interpolation calculations for LTT.
Part A: The simplified model used for computations
LTT requires to compute the end velocities (blue arrows in the drawing) of polyline points in the driver.
These velocities should be as large as possible, but respect the acceleration limit.
Consider the black nominal path with two points, pBefore and p, which results in the interpolated gray machine path.
Note that this is a simplification. At the very end of this document there's a transformation from this simple model
to what the machine actually needs, and a look into the bloody details of the machine.
We assume all lengths and angles to be small, so that a discrete differential is a valid approximation.
range of actually possible b (speed at p)
for given a (speed before) and length of c (max. acceleration)
To fix this case for arbitrary b: Reduce a until we are at case 1b with c=sin(alpha)*a.
range of actually possible b (speed at p)
for given a (speed before) and length of c (max. acceleration)
Law of cosines: c^2 = a^2 + b^2 - 2*a*b*cos(alpha)
solve to obtain two solutions b = a * cos(alpha) +- sqrt(a^2*(cos(alpha)^2 - 1) + c^2)
where (cos^2-1) is equal to the numerically better -sin^2, so
The "+" solution is the maximum speed possible for b.
The "-" solution is the minimum speed possible for b (!!!!)
b is not arbitrary because the algorithm never increases speed, just decreases, to ensure convergence.
(and the algorithm, by design, never increases the (candidate) velocity of a point)
(the currently stored value of b is less than the "-" solution from case 3)
Solve this by going back to case 3 by reducing a until law of cosines is fulfilled:
solve c^2 = ... for a, this yields (note that the equation is symmetric w.r.t. swapping b and a)
(The minimum possible value for a would be a_reduced_min = ... - sqrt(...) )
Part B: "The ugly truth" - transformation to machine data
Above, we calculated the velocities at the corner points, assuming the machine does some magical smooth
interpolation inbetween. Reality rather looks like the following.
In the following, all bold-print variables are vectors.
Consider the following sequence of commands and the resulting path and speed:
Actually, if the segment is much longer than needed for acceleration, it may also look like this:
The details of angled curves will be described in the next section.
For now, assume that ABC is a straight line only in X-direction,
and take a look at the resulting velocity over time:
For computations, you can assume that it's linearly interpolated:
(Reality is a little more complicated, you can "measure" it by accessing the servo controllers with
the SigmaWin Windows software and a USB cable. But the above is detailed enough for the computations.)
The speed specified by the PE command is the setpoint between the previous and the following point,
for example, in the middle between A and B the speed is PE_speed_B.
The computations described in the first part of this document compute v_A and v_B.
To convert to machine commands, choose PE_speed_B = v_A/2 + v_B/2.
B.2 Angled curves and the actual computation goal
For angled curves (not only in X- or Y-direction, but diagonal), the story is a little more complicated
The machine's interpolation is kind of stupid, not what you'd expect from high-price engineering.
The machine only cares about the faster axis (the one which travels more in the current move),
does all acceleration limiting only for this axis, and the other axis just blindly follows this pace
along the polyline. Of course, it's physically impossible to make an angled corner with finite
acceleration but nonzero speed, so the servo controller will get an impossible setpoint trajectory
and the lowpass dynamics of the control loop and the mechanics will smooth out the corner a little.
See the following sketch at A and B:
Shortly before B, the velocity is v_B pointing in (B-A) direction. Then it jumps to
v_target_shortly_after_B of same magnitude, but direction (C-B).
Therefore, if the time for the segment BC is significantly longer than the settling time (assume ca 5-10ms),
then the problematic acceleration is due to this jump:
To simplify the algorithm, in this case just assume that the entire time dt from B to C is only the settling time,
and continue with the following normal case:
Normally (i.e., if there is no corner at B, or the time BC is less than the settling time discussed before),
the acceleration which must be limited is
dt = ds / v_average (if dt > settling_time and ABC is not a straight line, use dt=settling_time instead to handle the "corner jump" acceleration.)
This means we can just use the computations from section A and in the end transform them as in section B.1,
and don't really need to understand what's going on except for the settling-time
Start and endpoints have v_Start = v_C = 0. The equations are analogous to above.
If "Arc compensation" is disabled in the laser's firmware (not recommended), then,
in the middle of every line the faster axis has the speed given by the PE command. Effectively,
If "Arc compensation" is enabled (recommended), then in the middle of every line the actual velocity is what you want:
|v_AB_mid| = PE_speed_B. (This is uncertain, you may want to do own measurements with different angles in joint-curve mode).
